Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant: Local Media and Language Revitalization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The diversity of human languages is a testament to the ingenuity and intellectual complexity of our species. Research throughout the world reveals that significant knowledge about how the world works, including unique and often valuable knowledge about the natural environment, is encoded differently in different languages. The loss of a language, then, is a fundamental loss not only to the people who speak that language but also to humanity's intellectual repertoire. Yet, it is widely recognized that in the United States, as well as worldwide, many languages are endangered. By most estimates, at least half of the world's approximately 6,000 languages will cease to be spoken by 2100. Although mass media have frequently been blamed for aggravating language loss, local communities have begun to develop their own radio and television programming as a grassroots means to increase the use of endangered languages. Understanding the effects of these grassroots projects to save endangered languages is crucial for creating context-sensitive programs and policies that will protect humanity's collective knowledge. The research funded by this award will focus on one such grassroots project.

University of Michigan doctoral student Georgia Ennis, under the supervision of Dr. Bruce Mannheim, will conduct research among the lowland Quichua in the Ecuadorian Amazon, where irreplaceable knowledge about the local ecosystem is threatened by ongoing language shift towards Spanish. She will focus on grassroots language revitalization programs being carried out by Amazonian Quichua through community radio stations. This setting is particularly appropriate for the research due to well-established community radio infrastructure in the region, which is now being consciously mobilized to increase the use of lowland Quichua. Studying radio may be especially productive, as it remains one of the most widespread, easy to use, and inexpensive media technologies. The investigator will assess whether radio production and broadcasting in an endangered language help maintain or even increase its use among listeners. She will also explore how media production may alter the speech of listeners and ultimately the language itself. The investigator will conduct long-term research at local radio stations and in Quichua communities in order to track the effects of radio media production and reception on language use. Data will be collected through multiple social science methods including surveys and observation of language use, habits of media consumption, and linguistic attitudes and beliefs. She will also collect and archive samples of language use by listeners and non-listeners for comparative analysis. The results of this research will provide insights into the viability of media production as a strategy for revitalization of endangered languages. Findings will also contribute to theories of how and why languages change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research found that radio media production can be a significant strategy for maintaining and transmitting endangered linguistic practices and cultural knowledge to audience members. Using social science methods, the investigator conducted long-term research at local radio stations and in indigenous communities in order to track the effects of radio media production and reception on language use. The investigator carried out research with hosts and producers of three popular radio programs, as well as with local performance and musical groups. She also carried out studies of reception of radio media and intergenerational language transmission in local homes.

This research has produced a rich body of linguistic and cultural data on Amazonian Quichua radio production, which promises to have an impact on the fields of anthropology, linguistics, and media studies. Preliminary results of this research have already been shared with interested community members. Selected recordings have also been archived with the Indigenous Language Archive of Ecuador, and further archival is planned. Preliminary results have further been shared with academic audiences through talks and presentations. Once published, the results of this research will be a valuable resource for policymakers and community members to formulate context-sensitive language revitalization and language planning initiatives.

The results of this research provide insights into the viability of media production as a strategy for revitalization of endangered languages. This research shows that local media production in indigenous languages is an important method for supporting indigenous language vitality. Quichua radio programs in the Ecuadorian Amazon are a key part of a growing indigenous media industry. This local indigenous media industry provides new opportunities for fluent, knowledgeable speakers to transmit significant ways of speaking in Quichua. It also encourages young people to become more involved in learning indigenous language and cultural practices both directly as performers, or more indirectly as audience members, thereby encouraging the maintenance of socially meaningful ways of speaking in indigenous languages. This research thus demonstrates that local radio media production may be beneficial to adopt as a language revitalization strategy in other contexts. Radio media production may be particularly effective in situations of recent language shift where there are still knowledgeable speakers, who may be unable for various reasons to directly transmit their language and knowledge. Findings of this research will also contribute to theories of how and why languages change. This research shows that radio media production is well-suited to the transmission of indigenous languages and information about cultural practices. However, it also indicates that producers and performers adjust their speech in various ways during presentations. Changes in speech in radio media resulted from larger changes due to broader patterns of language shift, as well as because of the constraints of different media formats. This suggests that radio and other forms of media should be used alongside other methods of language revitalization, in order to best transmit the greatest diversity of linguistic practices of an endangered language. The investigator has shown with empirically grounded social science data the beneficial effects of indigenous radio media production for language revitalization projects.
